A.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
	POLICIES

The emergency response procedures for the facility are included as part of the "Training Programs" manual.  These procedures were designed to meet the following objectives:

	1.	To save lives.
	2.	To minimize and avoid injuries.
	3.	To protect the environment.
	4.	To minimize property damage.

The emergency response procedures provide the reporting and notification procedures, evacuation procedures, and mitigation procedures that may be implemented to ensure operators respond effectively to an emergency situation.  This manual is distributed to all plant personnel upon initial employment and is readily available at the facility. 

B.	STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The JFJ Bronco facility is located at 6342 Bystrum Avenue, in Ceres, California.  The facility is situated on 80 acres in a rural area located off of Keyes Road which is approximately 5 miles south from Highway 99 on Crows Landing Road.   With the exception of one chiller, all of the ammonia equipment is located outside throughout the facility.  There is one chiller, the mezzanine chiller, that is located inside.  It is isolated from personnel and the room is equipped with an ammonia sensor and exhaust fan.  The one-ton containers of sulfur dioxide are located outside in the crush area; however, the smaller cylinders are used throughout the plant. The facility was originally built in 1974.

AMMONIA
The low side of the refrigeration system typically uses one or more evaporators to remove heat from the space or products to be cooled.  An evaporator contains a set of continuous coils through which the refrigerant flows.  Due to the low pressures and corresponding low temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant quickly evaporates, absorbing a great deal of heat from the surrounding area.  To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid am

monia.

The low and high sides of the refrigeration system are separated by the compressor and the expansion valve.  The compressor is the driving force of the system.  It pulls refrigerant vapor from the evaporator (low side) at a rate that will maintain the evaporator pressure required for the desired operating temperature.  At the same time it pressurizes the warm vapor and forces it into the condenser and the high side of the system.  Refrigeration compressors on the market today are screw type, reciprocating, and centrifugal.  

Expansion valves regulate the flow of liquid refrigerant from the high side to the low side by causing a large pressure drop.  These valves are located between the receiver (high side) and the evaporator (low side).  This valve, coupled with the capacities of the compressor, can help regulate the pressure of the evaporator thereby creating the cooling capabilities of the system.  The high side of the refrigeration system consists of a condenser and a receiver.  Warm refrigerant vapor enters the condenser after it has been pressurized by the compressor.  A condenser will typically use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser.  As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from this vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the receiver.  The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side.  It also serves to hold the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating.

The JFJ Bronco ammonia systems are utilized in two processes that are connected and co-located:  Champagne and Main. JFJ Bronco's two ammonia refrigeration systems are closed systems that cycle the refrigerant, or ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again.  The systems, consisting of piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pre

ssure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for product and process equipment. 

Changes in pressure are directly related to changes in temperature: lowering the ammonia pressure lowers its temperature.  Low pressure (cold) liquid ammonia provides refrigeration by removing ambient heat.  Removal of ambient heat causes the liquid ammonia (contained within the system) to vaporize.  Heat is later removed from the ammonia as it is condensed back into a liquid.  Typical operating conditions range from approximately 27 psig on the low pressure side of each system to 200 psig on the high side.  

The maximum intended inventory of ammonia is of 200,000 pounds.

SULFUR DIOXIDE
Sulfur dioxide is used in the crush process.  Sulfur dioxide from a one-ton container is pushed, using house nitrogen at approximately 80 psi, through a flexible line to a filter.  Downstream of the filter, the sulfur dioxide flows through a rotameter, a solenoid valve, and into the crusher.  The pipeline is filled with sulfur dioxide up to the solenoid valve.  At this point, the flow is dependent on the demand at the crusher.  When the pump at the crusher is turned on, the solenoid valve opens allowing the flow of sulfur dioxide into the crusher unit.

The maximum intended inventory of sulfur dioxide is five one ton containers or 10,000 pounds. 


 C.	HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY

Worst Case Release Result Summary

Since this facility has two regulated substances, the Hazard Assessment analyzed the "worst case" release from both the ammonia refrigeration process and the sulfur dioxide process.  This comparison was prepared by releasing the contents of the largest vessel from each process and determining the maximum downwind distance to the respective toxic endpoint.  Using EPA Risk Management Program guidance documents, it was determined that the worst case release is from the ammonia refrigeration system because it has the potential to affect a larger number of off-

site receptors.

Scenario Description: The high pressure receiver at JFJ Bronco Winery is two vessels, one on top of the other, such that they act as one vessel.  Therefore the total quantity of ammonia in both vessels will comprise the largest vessel at the facility.  The horizontal vessels measure approximately 4.5' OD x 25' and 6.5' OD x 22'.  Assuming that these vessels are completely full, the total quantity is calculated tp be 43,960 pounds.  Since there these vessels are stored outside, no passive mitigation measures were applied to determine the release rate.  The release rate is the total quantity that could be inside these vessels, divided by 10 minutes: 4396 lbs/min.

The meteorological conditions used were 1.5 meters/second wind speed, and F stability.  The facility is located in a rural setting. The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration, November 1998, Exhibit 4-4, was used to determine the maximum downwind distance to 200 ppm. This release scenario reaches off-site and may affect population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release scenario.

Alternative Release Result Summary

Ammonia Scenario Description: A 0.25 inch diameter leak of high pressure liquid ammonia for one hour.  The quantity of ammonia released in one hour at this rate is 6000 pounds.  Since the majority of ammonia refrigeration equipment is located outside, no passive mitigation measures were applied.  Active mitigation measures including a remote emergency shut down switch was considered in determining the potential duration of the scenario.  

The meteorological conditions used were 3 meters/second wind speed, and D stability.  The facility is located in a rural setting. The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration, November 1998, Exhibit 4-5, was used to determine the maximum downwind distance to 200 ppm. This release scenario reaches off-site and may affect population receptors.  No environmental r

eceptors were affected by this potential release scenario.

Sulfur Dioxide Scenario Description: This scenario assumed a 0.5 inch leak from the liquid piping from the one ton container.  This size hole yields a release rate of 400 lbs/minute.  Since this equipment is located outside, no passive mitigation measures were incorporated.  In addition, it was also assumed that this release continued until the entire one ton container was emptied.

The meteorological conditions used were 3 meters/second wind speed, and D stability.  The facility is located in a rural setting. The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Waste Water Treatment Plants,  November 1998, Exhibit 4-16, was used to determine the maximum downwind distance to 3 ppm. This release scenario reaches off-site and may affect population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release scenario.

D.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Administrative Measures
The facility operates in accordance with International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards as well as practices taught by the Refrigeration Engineers and Technicians Association. 

Engineering Measures
The ammonia refrigeration systems are equipped with various automatic process controls which ensure safe and efficient operation of the compressors, condensers, chillers, jacketed tanks, pump package, suction traps, and solenoid valves.  In addition, pressure relief valves automatically engage in the event of overpressurization.

The refrigeration systems are equipped with various status indicators to monitor system parameters and to minimize the potential for ammonia-related accidents.  The monitoring systems consist of 1) indicators (pressure, temperature, and level), 2) alarms (pressure, temperature, and level), and 3) routine inspections.  Pressure/temperature indicators are located throughout the system.  Level indicators, such as a sight glass, are

located on vessels maintaining a liquid level (e.g. high pressure receiver and the pump package vessel).  System alarms are activated at the control panel.

In addition, operations are monitored through routine system inspections conducted by qualified operators and mechanics.  Operators are always on-site during times of system operation.

E.	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no reported releases of ammonia or sulfur dioxide at this facility over the last five years (June 21, 1994 through June 21, 1999).

F.	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The following summarizes the emergency response and notification procedures at the facility.  

1.	In the event of a spill, release, near miss, or threatened release involving ammonia, evacuate the immediate area and report the situation to the area supervisor.  If appropriate, hit the system emergency stop button.

2.	Area supervisor will contact the Plant Manager and the Chief Engineer.  If both are not available (e.g. off-site), then the highest ranking supervisor on-site is contacted at the front office.  If needed, the Plant Manager and Chief Engineer are contacted using pagers and/or telephone calls.

3.	When the evacuation alarm sounds, all employees should follow the evacuation procedures and evacuate the plant to ensure their safety. Currently, the facility evacuates its employees by the use of an alarm system and personal communication.  It is the responsibility of the management and supervisory staff to notify all employees of the need to evacuate.

4.	Call 911 to ensure public safety.  The Chief Engineer or his designated alternate will evaluate the situation and determine appropriate response measures (e.g. use remote emergency switch to shut down equipment, clean up spills, etc.).

5.	Notify the Stanislaus County Department of Environmental Resources, Hazardous Materials Division at (209) 525-6700 (after hours contact (209) 525-7911, ask for pager 141).  The following information should be relayed to the Coun

ty:

	 	Address of the plant.
	 	Caller's name and name of the company.
	 	Name of the hazardous material released.
	 	Time of the release.
	 	Quantity of hazardous chemical released.

6.	If more than 100 pounds of ammonia or 1 pound of sulfur dioxide is released within a 24 hour period, the National Response Center at 1-800-424-8802 and the Stanislaus County Department of Environmental Resources Hazardous Material Division at 209-525-6700 should be notified immediately.

7.	If serious injuries or harmful exposures to workers occurs, call the nearest Cal/OSHA field office in Modesto at 209-576-6260.

8.	Within 48 hours, a complete investigation must be performed.

9.	Within 30 days of the release, the Emergency Release Follow-up Notice Reporting Form must be completed and sent to the Chemical Emergency Planning and Response Center (CEPRC) Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) in Sacramento.

G.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

There were several recommendations resulting from the development of the PSM/RMP document including recommendations from the Process Hazard Analysis and Off-Site Consequence Analysis studies.  These Teams made several procedural/managerial recommendations to improve safety at the facility.  The majority of these recommendations are expected to be implemented by December 1999; however, there are a couple that will require additional time and the anticipated completion date is July 1, 2000. Some of these changes are listed as follows:

CHAMPAGNE SYSTEM
	Install an emergency shut off valve on the liquid outlet line of the Champagne System's High Pressure Receiver (as close to the vessel as feasible).  

	Connect the shut off valve in NH3-R01 to remote emergency shut down buttons located in areas away from the ammonia systems. 

	Examine the release locations of all ammonia pressure relief valves at the facility and redirect the exhaust from any relief valve that currently exhausts in a location that could injure nearby personnel.  COMPLETED

ON 6/30/98

	Implement written procedures to replace ammonia pressure relief valves according to manufacturer specifications or industry standards (every five years).

	Verify that all relief valves on the high pressure side of the system are set sufficiently higher than the compressor high pressure safety shut down setting.  COMPLETED ON 3/1/97

	Decide upon the appropriate shut down mechanism for the ammonia systems and implement accordingly (e.g. will one switch be used to shut down the compressors and the Champagne System High Pressure Receiver or will two be used).  

	Review the existing locations for eyewash stations/safety showers and install additional units as needed.  Otherwise, require in the facility's written procedures that ammonia personnel will carry portable eyewash kits whenever performing maintenance on the ammonia system.  

	Conduct and evaluate emergency drills at least annually.  

	Consider installing a facility-wide PA and alarm system.  

	Implement written procedures for transferring liquid between the Champagne System and the main system.  COMPLETED ON 4/20/99

	Verify compressor shut down mechanisms are tested at least annually and that these tests are incorporated into the formal maintenance program.   COMPLETED ON 2/27/97

	Install check valve on the Champagne System High Pressure receiver liquid inlet line.

MAIN SYSTEM

	Install a solenoid valve (with remote shut off switches) on the liquid outlet line of the Main Refrigeration Plant High Pressure Receiver (as close to the vessel as feasible).

	Verify that the written procedures for ammonia deliveries require a facility operator to be present during the entire delivery period.  COMPLETED ON 2/27/97

	Install a check valve on each ammonia fill line at the facility.  Otherwise, ensure that ammonia deliveries will only connect to a fill line with a check valve.  COMPLETED ON 5/1/99

	Consider installing a permanent dike to ensure that a liquid release from the Main Refrigeration Plan

t Low Pressure Pumping Plant will flow into the sump.

Consider installing dual reliefs on the Main Refrigeration Plant Low Pressure Pumping Plant and traps.  COMPLETED ON 5/1/99

	Connect the outlet solenoid on the Main Refrigeration Plant Back Receiver to remote shut-off switches.  COMPLETED ON 8/1/98

	Consider insulating any water lines exposed to sunlight that feed the eyewash stations/safety showers.  COMPLETED ON 5/1/99

	Cap off valves at the end of ammonia lines that could be accidently opened and cause a release.  COMPLETED ON 9/1/97

	Replace annually the flexible hoses used to connect the portable trailers to the plant's refrigeration system.  COMPLETED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS

	Install remote shut off switches for the compressors on the portable trailers.  COMPLETED ON 10/1/98

	Examine the release locations of all ammonia pressure relief valves on the portable trailers and redirect the exhaust from any relief valve that currently exhausts in a location that could injure nearby personnel.  COMPLETED ON 8/1/97

	Consider adding remote emergency shut off switches to close the solenoid valve on the reservoir's liquid outlet line located on each portable trailer.

	Obtain maintenance records from the contractor for the portable trailers.

	Verify that written procedures are implemented to operate the portable trailers.

SULFUR DIOXIDE SYSTEM

	Consider installing emergency shut off valve with remote shut off switches on the sulfur dioxide one ton cylinders.

	Install a regulator on the house nitrogen feed.

	Require leak tests (e.g. soapy water) as part of the written procedures for connecting cylinders of sulfur dioxide.

	Conduct an annual check of the SO2 system for fittings, etc.

	Consider installing a venturi ejector for each sulfur dioxide connection to each must pump line.

	Evaluate whether one or two eyewash stations/safety showers should be installed in the crusher area.  Install accordingly.

	Add goggles and gloves to the required safety equipment t
o be worn by operators switching sulfur dioxide one ton cylinders.
